title: Great app, despite occasional inconsistencies
text:
I have had 11 Hunter-Douglas PowerView shades for the past 4 months, and added a 12th just last week. I‚Äôm an app developer, and I‚Äôve been impressed with everything Hunter-Douglas got right: the UI is especially intuitive, and for the most part, the app and especially the shades have been rock-solid reliable. 

However ‚Äî there‚Äôs a continuing issue with the app occasionally not setting the scene data in the hub correctly. It appears as if the scene data can somehow get corrupted between creating/modifying a scene, and then transmitting that scene data to be stored in the hub. 

This issue was verified when Hunter-Douglas‚Äô superb support technician guided me to slightly change the scene data, causing it to be written out to the hub again. That solved my problem. 

As an app developer it appears to be an initialization or corruption issue, which could be tracked down by embedding more data validation into the app. I might suggest the data be checksummed and the checksum be stored both in the app and on the hub. That way, any degradation of data could be automatically detected and perhaps the issue could be found and corrected. 

All that said, the above issue is mostly a temporary frustration: the product has been a pleasure to work with, and now that HomeKit is supported, I can ask Siri to invoke any scene.

So I‚Äôm required to go into my device settings and disable zoomed mode in order to continue using the app. Similar experience when editing scenes: most of the scene icons don‚Äôt render on the screen in zoomed mode. title: Reliability Issues
text:
I wish I could be enthusiastic about the PowerView app but I'm disappointed. On paper, it sounds great. In use, the system isn't reliable. We added motorization to nine of the 19 window coverings. Half of the powered shades work reliably. The other half seem to have minds of their own. Sometimes they respond to the app. Sometimes they don't. It appears that some shades don't wake up from standby mode like they should.

Using the pebble remote will often (but not always) wake up a non-responsive shade and enable it to be controlled by the PowerView app. I've tried rebooting the hub and deleting shade memory but the results are hit and miss. I ended up deleting a couple shades to start over but they're still not reliable even after reprogramming. All PowerView-enabled shades are in the same room together with the hub. I added a repeater device but this doesn't help either.

The app shows signal strength and battery level for each shade. The obstinate shades sometimes show a green status, presumably indicating all is good, but at other times the battery level and signal strength icons are grayed out. Batteries are brand new in all shades--they were just installed.

Nest integration would be great if it worked reliably. When Nest determines no one is home, most of the shades move into the appropriate position, but there's always one or two that don't cooperate.

Similarly, because PowerView communications are unreliable with half the shades, the automation routines just cause eye-rolls when shades refuse to cooperate. Some stay open when they're supposed to close. Some stay closed when they're supposed to open. Hub reboots don't fix the problem, nor does deleting shade memory or removing shades completely. As mentioned earlier, using the pebble remote often jump starts the communication between the hub and shade and re-enables app control.

We chose Hunter Douglas because of the reputation for quality but PowerView automation still needs work.

text:
This could be such a cool system but after spending $10,000.00 for nine of their top of the line blinds and months spent programming and reprogramming the app, I am disappointed and frustrated by my investment. 

I am lucky that I am computer literate because my dealer had no expertise in setting up the blinds and after three or four hours, I finally just told him to forget about it. 

After many hours over several days and two fruitless calls to customer service (all they did was read, word for word, the awful set up brochure), I finally got the blinds to somewhat do what I wanted. In fairness, their online PDF help file is much more informative but still hard to navigate. 

Now six months later, they still work correctly only about 75% of the time. Often at night one or two blinds will fail to close or in the morning one or two will fail to open. Using "scenes" will often result in erratic results as well. Unpredictable. 

When I am away from home (I travel a lot which was one of the reasons I bought these), I have no confidence that my blinds have closed properly and indeed often they don't. 

This blind system came highly recommended and my expectations were high so when they fail to work I am left feeling screwed.

The result is frequent resetting of the hub, scrambling to find a repeater that will talk to the shades, and trying each of our phones and iPads to regain control. Scheduled events have yet to operate. However, there is a lot of promise if they ever work out the bugs. Hopefully there will be an update to iron out the bugs.
